person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_448.name: DiodorusSiculus
person_448.description: Of Sicily was an ancient Greek historian. He is known for writing the monumental universal history Bibliotheca historica, in forty books, fifteen of which survive intact, between 60 and 30 BCE.

person_795.name: Jupiter
person_795.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

person_689.name: FrancisWilford
person_689.description: Indologist, Orientalist, member of the Asiatic Society of Bengal, and constant contributor to its journal, Asiatic Researches, for which he wrote a number of unreliable articles on ancient Hindu geography, mythography and other subjects.

person_443.name: Manetho
person_443.description: Egyptian priest, from Sebennytos, who lived in the Ptolemaic Kingdom during the Hellenistic period. He wrote the Aegyptiaca (History of Egypt) in Greek, a major chronological source for the reigns of the kings of ancient Egypt.

person_800.name: Amenophis
person_800.description: Also known as Akhenaten, Egyptian pharaoh who radically reformed Egyptian religion.

person_444.name: Sesostris
person_444.description: Also spelled Sesoösis or Sesonchosis, was a legendary king of ancient Egypt who, according to Herodotus, led a military expedition into parts of Europe.

person_801.name: Herodotus
person_801.description: Greek historian and geographer who wrote a detailed account of the Greco-Persian Wars - one the earliest existing historical texts.

person_705.name: JohnBentley
person_705.description: Member of the Asiatic Society in Calcutta who wrote on Hindu astronomy.

person_439.name: Jean SylvainBailly
person_439.description: French astronomer, mathematician, and political leader of the early part of the French Revolution.

person_085.name: Plato
person_085.description: A pupil of Socrates, much of Plato's large corpus of surviving philosophical texts are written in the form of Socratic dialogues. He espoused a philosophical idealism including the primacy of mathematics and an anti-democratic political philosophy because of the execution of Socrates. Plato's writings have been, and are, so influential that all subsequent philosophy has been described as footnotes to Plato.

person_266.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
person_266.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

person_130.name: Pierre-SimonLaplace
person_130.description: French mathematician seen as the Newton of France. He met Davy in 1813 and 1820. ForMemRSL.

person_189.name: WilliamWordsworth
person_189.description: English poet who, with Samuel Taylor Coleridge, published Lyrical Ballads. Davy contributed to seeing the second edition (1800) through the press in Bristol. Poet Laureate from 1843.

person_401.name: JuliusCaesar
person_401.description: Roman general and dictator who first landed an army in Britain. Assassinated to prevent him gaining total power in Rome.

person_445.name: Pythagoras
person_445.description: Pythagoras of Samos was an ancient Ionian Greek philosopher, polymath, and the eponymous founder of Pythagoreanism. Believed in the primacy of number.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_440.name: Jean Joseph MarieAmiot
person_440.description: French Jesuit priest, who worked in Qing China, during the reign of the Qianlong Emperor.

person_807.name: Chin ChiHoang
person_807.description: Now transliterated as Qin Shi Huang Di, the first Chinese emperor.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_978.name: Libya
place_978.description: Libya, officially the State of Libya, is a country in the Maghreb region of North Africa.

place_979.name: Red Sea
place_979.description: A seawater inlet of the Indian Ocean, lying between Africa and Asia.

place_518.name: Ganges
place_518.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

place_820.name: Lake Baikal
place_820.description: Lake Baikal is an ancient, massive lake in the mountainous Russian region of Siberia, north of the Mongolian border. Considered the deepest lake in the world, it’s circled by a network of hiking paths called the Great Baikal Trail.

place_980.name: Sais, Egypt
place_980.description: An ancient Egyptian city in the Western Nile Delta. On its ruins today stands the town of Sa el-Hagar or Sa El Hajar.

place_981.name: Memphis
place_981.description: The ancient capital of Inebu-hedj, the first nome of Lower Egypt. Its ruins are located in the vicinity of the present-day village of Mit Rahina.

place_982.name: Babylon
place_982.description: An ancient city located on the lower Euphrates river in southern Mesopotamia, within modern-day Iraq.

place_580.name: Balkh
place_580.description: Balkh is a town in the Balkh Province of Afghanistan.

place_581.name: Samarkand
place_581.description: Samarkand, or Samarqand, is a city in south-eastern Uzbekistan and among the oldest continuously inhabited cities in Central Asia.

place_983.name: Chaldea
place_983.description: A small country that existed between the late 10th or early 9th and mid-6th centuries BC, after which the country and its people were absorbed and assimilated into the indigenous population of Babylonia.

place_984.name: Pekin
place_984.description: A historic spelling of a name of Beijing, the capital of China.

otherwork_167.name: Asiatick Researches, Or, Transactions of the Society Instituted in Bengal, for Inquiring Into the History and Antiquities, the Arts, Sciences, and Literature of Asia

otherwork_207.name: Discourse the Eleventh, on the Philosophy of the Asiaticks
otherwork_207.author: William Jones
